awd_titl_txt: Catalytic and Catalytically Relevant Formation, Activation and Functionalization of Covalent Bonds by Late Transition Metal Complexes
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Catalysis Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Alan Goldman at Rutgers University is developing new catalytic reactions to add molecules together to former larger, more complex ones.  The overall goal is to develop new catalysts and catalytic processes that are both synthetically useful and practical.   Professor Goldman is also studying the reaction mechanisms (i.e., how the reactions work) and the factors that control the chemistry of the catalytic reactions, which will help to optimize the outcomes of the catalysis and to add to our fundamental knowledge base about chemistry.  The development of new catalytic conversions may lead to new routes to products ranging from fuels to plastics to pharmaceuticals. Products from catalysis technology have been estimated to account for nearly 20% of the U.S. Gross Domestic Product (GDP), so the potential impacts of such new chemistry could be broad. Graduate and undergraduate students are receiving broad training in chemical synthesis, characterization, mechanistic study, and computational molecular design, which are important for success in any scientific problem-solving endeavor related to catalysis. Participants in the project are beginning a collaboration with the Liberty Science Center in Jersey City, NJ to co-design an interactive touch-table exhibit for visitors to "virtually synthesize" common household chemicals such as aspirin and plastics. Eventually the plan is to expand this exhibit to other science centers, and possibly to other platforms such as personal computers, tablets, or smart phones.

Professor Goldman is studying fundamental oxidative addition and M-X insertion reactions of late-transition-metal catalysts and their microscopic reverse.  New SiNP, PC(4-py)P, and chiral PCP pincer ligands are being synthesized, complexed to iridium metal centers and studied for olefin insertions into M-X bonds, cleavage and insertions into C-O bonds, and ortho-directed insertions into aryl C-H bonds.  Catalytic C-H bond functionalization is often frustrated by the fact that potential reagents such as carbon monoxide bind strongly bind to the coordination sites typically required to activate the C-H bond. Professor Goldman is studying how Bronsted acids catalyze C-H addition to metal carbonyl complexes that do not readily add additional equivalents of carbon monoxide. This chemistry potentially is the means to develop a hydrocarbon carbonylation catalyst.  Fundamental studies of insertion into M-X bonds and C-X addition/elimination reactions (particularly X = O and N) will inform the development of new and more effective catalysts of this type.  This chemistry eventually could impact commodity and fine chemical synthesis technology.

por.por_cntn:
Under the auspices of this grant we have made significant progress toward the development of catalytic systems with potential applications for an extremely wide range of chemical syntheses. Targets, actual and potential, include fuels, commodity chemicals, and fine chemicals such as pharmaceutical precursors.

Particular focus has been on the manipulations of inert carbon-hydrogen bonds, especially those of alkanes and alkyl groups. Alkanes are the major constituent of petroleum and natural gas, and the major component of liquid fuels from fossil sources. Looking toward the near future, synthetic liquid fuels, for example those produced from carbon dioxide and water with the use of renewable energy sources, will also presumably comprise mainly alkanes. Alkyl groups are chemically almost identical to alkanes and are found in the majority of large-scale chemical products (e.g. polymers) and many high-value chemicals.

Alkanes are notoriously inert, and it is particularly difficult to effect their chemical transformations selectively, but great progress has been made in recent years toward this end through the development of transition-metal based molecular catalysts. Nevertheless, an understanding of the factors that govern the activity of transition metal centers toward C-H bonds has been elusive. Under the auspices of this grant we have made major contributions to the development of such an understanding. The factors elucidated are also largely applicable to other important covalent bonds including N-H and H-H. Intertwined with fundamental questions, we have developed new catalysts, and have extended their substrate scope, most notably to the dehydrogenation of amines to give enamines.

C-H bonds are ubiquitous in organic chemistry, and as such the ability to manipulate them has actual and potential applications which extend well beyond alkanes and alkyl groups. Alcohols for example, like alkanes, have aliphatic C-H bonds. The cleavage of alcohol C-O bonds is a reaction of great interest for many applications including, perhaps most notably, conversion of biomass to fuels and chemicals. Glycerol is a highly abundant by-product of biodiesel formation; indeed the economics of biodiesel formation may depend in significant part on our ability to valorize glycerol. We have discovered a catalyst for the C-O bond cleavage reaction of conversion of glycerol to give the very desirable chemical 1,2-propanediol. Although C-H activation and C-O cleavage are typically thought of as unrelated, our system operates via initial addition of a C-H bond, followed by metal assisted loss of OH- from the adjacent carbon.

We have also studied another class of reactions, carbonylation, the installation of a C-O group into an organic molecule. Our emphasis has been on the carbonylation of alkanes; this closely ties to our C-H activation chemistry, but carbonylation has numerous applications in synthetic fuels as well as commodity and fine chemicals. The key and often rate-limiting step in carbonylation catalyses is typically insertion of CO into a metal-alkyl bond. It has long been known that such insertions are promoted by polar organic molecules but the mechanism for this effect has remained a mystery. We have elucidated a completely unanticipated mechanism for which we provided compelling computational evidence. Based on the mechanistic understanding that we have developed, we have computationally predicted and experimentally verified that pyridine N-oxides are the most active catalysts for this reaction reported to date.

Integrating our C-H activation and carbonylation work, we have investigated systems for alkane hydrocarbonylation. We previously  discovered that Bronsted acids catalyzed the oxidative addition of C(sp)-H bonds by an iridium carbonyl complex. Under the auspices of this grant we find that acids catalyze the analogous reaction of alkane C-H bonds, but the thermodynamics lead in the reverse direction. However if an uphill C-H addition were followed by downhill carbonylation and hydrogenation, the overall reaction would be the hydrocarbonylation of an alkane. Of particular interest, hydrocarbonylation of methane would give ethanol which can of course be used directly as transportation fuel or converted to heavier fuels and chemicals. 

CH4 + CO + H2 → CH3CH2OH

We have made substantial progress in this area. We recently discovered that under an atmosphere of H2 and CO, the complex (PCP)Ir(CO)(H)(CH3) reacts to give ethanol, regenerating (PCP)Ir(CO). Thus C-H addition of methane to (PCP)Ir(CO) under these conditions would yield ethanol. In accord with this point, we find that (PCP)Ir(CO) catalyzes conversion of olefins to the homologous alcohols. This reaction presumably proceeds through intermediates (PCP)Ir(CO)(alkyl)(H) in which the alkyl group is formed not via C-H addition, but via insertion of olefin into an Ir-H bond.

Thus all the components of the alkane hydrocarbonylation cycle have been observed individually and/or in catalytic cycles, but with the key alkane addition step only proceeding in the "wrong" direction, i.e. C-H elimination. Current studies are therefore focused on developing analogous carbonyl complexes for which the thermodynamics of C-H addition are less endergonic, enough so that incorporation into an (overall exergonic) catalytic cycle is feasible.
